Murzin a ⁎ a Laboratory of Industrial Chemistry and Reaction Engineering, Process Chemistry Centre, Åbo Akademi University, Biskopsgatan 8, 20500 Turku/Åbo, Finland b Technical Chemistry, Department of Chemistry, Chemical–Biological Center, Umeå University, SE-90187 Umeå, Sweden ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract Highlights ► Replacement of toxic chemicals such as phosgene with CO2. ► Shift of equilibrium towards DMC formation via water removal. ► Qualitative kinetics and kinetic modelling. ► Reaction mechanism and estimation of kinetic parameters. A kinetic investigation of dimethyl carbonate (DMC) synthesis from methanol and CO2 over ZrO2–MgO was performed by using butylene oxide as a chemical trap for the water formed during the reaction. The effect of the catalyst amount, the stirring speed, the temperature, as well as the amount of butylene oxide on the reaction rate and the selectivity to DMC was studied. The analysis of the reaction pathway suggests that DMC and butylene glycol are formed via the reaction of adsorbed mono-methoxycarbonate intermediate and methoxybutanol or methanol. A kinetic model was developed based on the reaction mechanism and it was in agreement with the experimental data. The apparent activation energy for the formation of DMC was 62kJ/mol. The utilisation of CO2 as a carbon resource for the benign synthesis of chemicals is of particular interest, since CO2 is abundant, affordable, non-toxic and non-flammable. This synthetic methodology favours the implementation of more direct reaction pathways with a high atom efficiency and at the same time, avoiding the use of toxic chemicals, such as phosgene. In spite of these advantages, industrial utilisation of CO2 in chemical syntheses remains a significant challenge, because it lays in a deep potential energy well (−400kJ/mol), requiring huge amounts of energy for activation [2]. To overcome this challenge, high temperatures, extremely reactive reagents, metal salts, photochemical and electrochemical energy have been proposed [3–6] as tools to mimic natural phenomena such as photosynthesis. CO2 can therefore be used in reactions, such as the synthesis of organic carbonates in which the –COO– moiety is maintained. Dimethyl carbonate (DMC) has attracted much attention as an environmentally benign and important carbonylating and methylating reagent replacing toxic phosgene, methyl iodide and dimethyl sulphate traditionally used [7,8]. DMC is also an intermediate for the synthesis of higher carbonates and carbamates and as an electrolyte in the production of lithium batteries [9]. Several routes have been developed for the synthesis of DMC, such as methanol phosgenation, oxidative carbonylation of methanol, methanolysis of urea, transesterification of cyclic carbonates, as well as the direct synthesis from CO2 and methanol. Although methodologies such as phosgenation are credited for their high reactivity and high productivity of DMC, the toxicity of phosgene both to health and the environment limits its applications for cleaner syntheses. Among the DMC synthesis technologies, the direct reaction of CO2 and methanol is the most attractive route from the viewpoint of green chemistry and sustainable development. The direct route is among the most efficient in terms of the atom economy, producing only water as a by-product. This process undoubtedly results in environmental and economic benefits with waste minimisation. However, the thermodynamic limitations embedded in the process [10], and the inertness of CO2 restrain the synthesis of DMC in high yields. In order to overcome these obstacles, the removal of water from the catalytic reaction system using acetonitrile or trimethoxymethane as promoters [11,12] have been proposed. The use of butylene oxide as a chemical water scavenger [13] has also been demonstrated in the presence of ZrO2–MgO catalyst resulting in 7.2% yield and 53% selectivity to DMC. To understand the chemical processes occurring at the molecular level, a detailed kinetic description is required. Knowledge and transformation of such data into mathematical models can foster the design and reaction intensification aspects of chemical processes. In this paper, kinetic investigations to understand the detailed reaction mechanism leading to these improved yields under different conditions using ZrO2–MgO catalysts are reported. The influence of the reaction parameters on the synthesis of DMC was examined and the interactions of carbon dioxide and methanol with the catalyst surface were discussed. In addition, a kinetic model was developed based on the experimental data. The activation energy of the reaction was estimated from the kinetic model at different temperatures. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Zirconyl nitrate, aqueous ammonium hydroxide (28%), methanol (99.8%), butylene oxide (99%), DMC (99%), and magnesium nitrate, were purchased from Sigma–Aldrich. CO2 (99.99%) was purchased from AGA. All chemicals were used as received. 2.2 Catalyst synthesis and characterisation The catalyst was synthesised by the co-precipitation of 0.5M solution of zirconyl nitrate and 0.3M solution of magnesium nitrate hydrate in 500ml followed by the drop-wise addition of ammonium hydroxide under stirring until the pH was adjusted to 9. The precipitate obtained was aged for 3 days, while maintaining the pH at 9 by a constant addition of appropriate amounts of NH4OH. The precipitate was washed several times after ageing with distilled water to remove the unreacted NH4OH. The resulting cake was dried and calcined at 700°C for 3h to obtain a white powder (MgO–ZrO2). The specific surface area of the catalyst was determined by measuring the nitrogen adsorption–desorption isotherms at 77K (Sorptomatic 1900) in liquid nitrogen. Prior to the measurements, the samples were outgassed for 3h at 473K to a residual pressure below 0.01Pa. The total surface area calculated according to the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) [14] equation was 55m2/g. 2.3 Experimental setup and catalytic tests All the reactions were performed in a high pressure autoclave (Parr Inc., volume 300ml) equipped with a stirrer, baffles and a sampling line controlled by a system of valves. The temperature in the reactor was regulated to an accuracy of ±1°C by a temperature controller. The stirrer operated with a system of four blade impellers rotating at 700rpm. In a typical reaction sequence, the catalyst (1g), methanol (695mmol, 28.1ml) and butylene oxide (21.3mmol, 1.8ml) were introduced into the reactor and purged with argon and then CO2 to expel any trapped gases. The reactor was pressurised to ca 4.5MPa with CO2 and then heated to the desired temperature (120, 150 or 180°C). At specific time intervals, samples were withdrawn and cooled in the sampling loop prior to the analysis. The samples were analysed by gas chromatography (Agilent Technologies, 6890N) with a 60m×320μm×0.5μm capillary column (J&W 123-506 E DB5) equipped with a flame ionisation detector and using 2-propanol as an internal standard. The products were identified by GC–MS (Agilent Technologies, 6890N). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Qualitative kinetics 3.1.1 Butylene oxide as water trap The substrates consisted of a mixture of methanol, CO2 and butylene oxide, and the catalyst composed of ZrO2 and MgO. Mixed oxides of Zr and Mg have previously demonstrated positive catalytic effects for the synthesis of DMC from methanol and CO2 in the presence of butylene oxide as water abstracting additive [13]. Since the concomitant production of water during this reaction essentially limits the synthesis of DMC in high yields, the in situ removal of the water from the reaction medium shifts the reaction equilibrium towards higher DMC yields (Scheme 1 ). Butylene glycol is formed from the reaction of butylene oxide with water, thereby limiting the hydrolysis of the DMC formed. The abstraction of water from the reaction medium leads to the relaxation of the thermodynamic constraints, consequently resulting in an increase in the yield of DMC. The water abstracting additive, however, reacts with methanol and CO2, forming methoxybutanol (1-methoxybutanol and 2-methoxybutanol) and butylene carbonate, respectively, as reaction intermediates. In addition, trace amounts of dimethyl ether were identified as a result of the dehydration of methanol. The maximum conversion of methanol and butylene oxide obtained after 26h at 150°C was 11.7% and 100%, respectively. The concentration variations of the species in the reaction mixture as a function of reaction time at 150°C and 9MPa are shown in Fig. 1 . The amount of DMC increased gradually as the reaction proceeded and levelled off after 9h, indicating the attainment of equilibrium. The conversion of butylene oxide after 7h was 90%, suggesting an increase in the accumulation of water as more DMC was produced. The decrease in the concentration of butylene oxide resulted in a corresponding increase in the amount of methoxybutanol or butylene carbonate, which eventually transform into butylene glycol by reacting with methanol. Methoxybutanol and butylene carbonate present as reaction intermediates increased steadily in the beginning of the reaction until 5h, after which the concentrations slowly decreased as DMC and butylene glycol were formed. The low concentration of butylene carbonate in comparison to methoxybutanol may be attributed to the slow reactivity of butylene oxide and CO2, and the decomposition of resulting butylene carbonate to methoxybutanol (Scheme 2 ). The yield of DMC obtained after 26h was 6.2% with 11.7% conversion of methanol. Comparing the amount of DMC and butylene glycol, the lower concentration of butylene glycol may be due to the formation of dibutylene glycol or water uptake by magnesium species in the catalyst. The results suggest that the reaction does not proceed primarily via the transesterification route although cycloaddition and transesterification are highly feasible in such catalytic systems. 3.1.2 Effect of stirring on DMC formation Kinetic results correlated to different reaction parameters can be meaningful only in the absence of mass transfer limitations. The reaction studied at 500, 700 and 900rpm did not show any appreciable difference in the formation of DMC. The results indicate that the experiments were conducted in the absence of mass transfer limitations when catalyst particles smaller than 100μm were used (Fig. 2 ). The mass transfer resulting from the film diffusion of CO2 into methanol and to the solid catalyst particles was minimised by the fast stirring speed and small catalyst particles used during the reaction. The presence of baffles ensured efficient mixing of the catalyst and substrates, and the rate was independent of the stirring speed used indicating that the reaction was performed in the kinetic regime. 3.1.3 Effect of catalyst particle size and catalyst loading on DMC formation The effect of internal mass transfer limitation was also investigated by comparing the catalyst particles below 63μm (average particle size 1.5nm) and 100μm (average particle size 2.1nm). The catalyst effectiveness was demonstrated by using minimal catalyst loading to obtain high yields of DMC. The effect of the catalyst loading and the catalyst particle size on the concentration of DMC yield over time is shown in Fig. 3 . The concentration of DMC increased steadily as the reaction progressed, but remained constant after 21h. This shows that the thermodynamic limitations initially suppressed by the use of butylene oxide resurface, and thus, the concentration of DMC remains constant. The initial rate of 1.2mmol/h was obtained using 0.5g catalyst during 5h. When the catalyst loading increased to 1g, the initial rate also doubled to 2.4mol/h. The proportional increase of the initial reaction rate with the catalyst loading suggests that the initial stage of the reaction is not controlled by gas–liquid mass transfer but by the intrinsic kinetics. However, the reaction rate for DMC formation decreased after 7h for both 1g and 0.5g of catalyst and remained constant after 21h. Since butylene oxide is completely used up, the formation of water may lead to further thermodynamic constraints restricting an increase in the DMC concentration. During 5h of the reaction, the concentration of methoxybutanol showed a maximum at ca 45% conversion of butylene oxide (Fig. 4 ), and increasing the concentrations of DMC and butylene glycol. The results also show that the formation rate DMC was independent of the catalyst particle size when efficient stirring speed of 700rpm was used. The effect of the diffusion resistance on the catalyst with particle sizes <63μm and <100μm was minimal, since the concentrations of DMC obtained were similar. This shows that for very slow reactions, such as the synthesis of DMC from methanol and CO2 using catalyst particles less than 100μm, the effect of the gas–liquid mass transfer may not influence the product formation. 3.1.4 Kinetic analysis of the effect of methanol/butylene oxide initial molar ratio The dependence of DMC on butylene oxide as a chemical dehydrating additive was investigated with different concentrations of methanol and butylene oxide. The influence of methanol-to-epoxide ratio on the yield and selectivity to DMC was studied at 150°C and 9.5MPa. The consumption of butylene oxide during the reaction resulted in the formation of methoxybutanol, butylene carbonate, butylene glycol and DMC in different molar ratios. A decrease in the molar ratio of methanol-to-butylene oxide in the substrate from 45 to 20 promoted the yield of DMC via the formation of methoxybutanol albeit a decrease in the selectivity (Fig. 5 ). When comparing the selectivity at the same conversion level of methanol e.g. 4%, it can be observed that the selectivity to DMC using Me:Bu=45, Me:Bu=30 and Me:Bu=20 was 61%, 41% and 33% respectively (Fig. 6 ). The results show that the presence of a limited amount of butylene oxide favours the nucleophilic attack of methanol on butylene oxide in comparison to the formation of butylene carbonate, resulting in the formation of methoxybutanol, which is eventually transformed to DMC and butylene glycol. An increase in the amount of butylene oxide in the substrate promoted reactions with both methanol and CO2, thus decreasing the selectivity of DMC. The concentration of DMC did not increase linearly as the concentration of butylene oxide in the substrate increased, showing that the reaction intermediates persist in the reaction medium decreasing the selectivity to DMC. The amount of methoxybutanol increased as the amount of butylene oxide in the substrate increased, owing to the ease of reactions in the liquid phase. The optimal molar ratio of 30 exhibiting a reasonable yield and selectivity towards DMC with maximum DMC conversion was used in the study. 3.1.5 Kinetic analysis of the effect of temperature on DMC synthesis The influence of temperature on the reaction kinetics of DMC synthesis was investigated at 120, 150 and 180°C at 9.5MPa. The initial rates for the conversion of methanol to DMC or to all other products were analysed during 5h at different temperatures (Eq. (1)) (1) R = r DMC ∑ r c , where R is the ratio of the rates, r c is the rate of the various components during 5h at a particular temperature. The ratios of the conversion of methanol-to-DMC to the conversion of methanol to all products were 0.56, 0.53 and 0.45 for 120, 150 and 180°C, respectively (Fig. 7 ). This shows that DMC selectivity decreased with an increase in temperature from 120 to 180°C. At low temperatures, the catalytic transformation of methanol over ZrO2–MgO results in the formation of DMC. At the same time, reactions at low temperatures limit the dehydration of methanol to dimethoxymethane and retard the liquid phase reaction of methanol and butylene oxide, thereby increasing the selectivity. Therefore, the conversion of methanol to DMC, methoxybutanol and other reaction products, such as dimethoxymethane depend on the reaction temperature. The rate of formation of DMC increased steadily with an increase of the reaction temperature and levelled off after ca 9h. The initial rates of DMC formation obtained during 5h at 120, 150 and 180°C were 0.9mmol/h, 2.4mmol/h and 2.7mmol/h, respectively (Fig. 8 ). At 180°C, the concentration of DMC remained constant at ca 0.7mol/l after 9h whereas a slow increase was observed at 120 and 150°C. This result indicates that equilibrium was established for the formation and consumption or hydrolysis of DMC, at high temperatures and for prolonged reaction times in accordance with earlier observations [13,15]. The formation rates of methoxybutanol and butylene carbonate also increased as the temperature increased due to the reactions of methanol and CO2 with butylene oxide. For example, at 5h, the conversion of methanol increased from 3.2mol% at 120°C to 10.3mol% at 180°C. Similarly, the butylene oxide conversion increased from 56mol% to 92mol% as the temperature increased from 120 to 180°C. The selectivity to DMC therefore decreases with increasing temperature (Fig. 9 ). Owing to the activation of methanol and CO2 at high temperature, higher DMC yields with a lower selectivity were obtained. In addition, dehydration of methanol leading to the formation of dimethoxymethane is favourable at higher temperatures. The optimum temperature of 150°C was therefore chosen for the reaction since a maximum yield and selectivity towards DMC were obtained, and desorption of CO2 and H2O from the catalyst surface can be achieved at this temperature [16]. The selectivity of DMC increased at the same conversion level of methanol with decreasing temperature, e.g. at the same conversion of 4%, a selectivity of 25% was obtained at 180°C while the selectivity at 120°C increased to 46%. This also shows that a lower temperature is favourable for the DMC formation although at a decreasing conversion of methanol. This can also be seen by comparing the conversion of methanol with the calculated consumption of methanol based on the formation of DMC. The amount of butylene glycol formed also increased with an increase in the temperature (Fig. 10 ) due to the dehydration of methanol to dimethyl ether and water, which further reacts with methoxybutanol or butylene oxide to yield butylene glycol and decreasing the selectivity to DMC. 4 Analysis of the reaction mechanism The weak basic and acidic sites as well as the tetragonal phase of ZrO2 have been found to be important for the synthesis of DMC [17] from methanol and CO2 in the presence of butylene oxide as a water trap. DMC synthesis is initiated by the adsorption of methanol as mono- or di-methoxide species on the surface of tetragonal phase of ZrO2, stabilised by MgO. The proton from methanol, at the same time, is transferred to the oxygen atom of ZrO2. The molecularly adsorbed methoxide species forms loose associations with the active sites of the catalyst, permitting further reactions with the carbonyl function of CO2. The dissolution and interaction of CO2 with the adsorbed methoxide groups result in the formation of mono-methyl carbonate species. This has been confirmed by spectroscopic studies for the elementary steps in DMC formation using Zr4+ or Cu+ as catalysts [18], and the in situ infrared and Raman studies using ZrO2 [19,20]. The reaction step involving the dissolution and reaction of CO2 is assumed to be slow, since CO2 remained non-activated and the reaction with the adsorbed methoxide species is slow. The nucleophilic attack of mono-methyl carbonate species on methoxybutanol, formed from the reaction of methanol and butylene oxide or cyclic carbonate, results in the formation of DMC and butylene glycol (Scheme 3 ). The protonation of methanol can also lead to the formation of methoxonium ions [CH3OH2]+. The nucleophilic attack of the methoxide group on the methoxonium ion results in the formation of dimethyl ether (DME) as a by-product. 5 Kinetic modelling 5.1 Derivation of kinetic model The main reactions leading to the formation of DMC, such as, adsorption of methanol and other species on the catalyst active sites, the reaction of the activated methanol with CO2 to form monomethyl carbonate species and the subsequent formation of DMC are described in Scheme 4 . Three main reaction products observed were DMC, butylene glycol and methoxybutanol with trace amounts of butylene carbonate. The Eley-Rideal type of reaction mechanism was adopted for the kinetic modelling, according to which the liquid reactants adsorb on the catalyst active sites and subsequently react with the dissolved CO2 from the gas phase. The pressure of CO2 in the reactor ensures that equilibrium is established between the CO2 dissolved in the liquid phase and the CO2 reacting with the activated methanol. Hence, it is convenient to express the reaction rate as a function of the CO2 pressure in the gas phase rather than the concentration of CO2 in the liquid phase. The mechanism also assumes that methanol adsorbs on the catalyst active sites preferentially to butylene oxide. This assumption is reasonable since the molar concentration of methanol is higher than the concentration of butylene oxide by a factor of 30. Quasi-equilibria were applied to all steps except the step involving the reaction of CO2, and the liquid-phase reaction of butylene oxide and methanol. DMC was formed via two parallel routes. Based on these hypotheses, the reaction steps leading to the formation of the products can be written as follows: N 1 N 2 N 3 1 MeOH + * ≡ MeOH * 1 2 0 2 MeOH * + CO 2 ⇔ MC * 1 1 0 3 MC * + MB ≡ DMC + BG + * 1 0 0 4 BO + MeOH ⇒ MB 0 0 1 5 MC * + MeOH * ≡ DMC + H 2 O + 2 * 0 1 0 (2) N 1 : MeOH + CO 2 + MB → DMC + BG N 2 : 2 MeOH + CO 2 → DMC + H 2 O N 3 : BO + MeOH → MB, where * is the free adsorption sites, A* is the adsorption of species A on the catalyst surface, N 1, N 2, N 3 are reaction routes and the numbers before the adsorptions/reactions are the reaction steps. After these steps stoihiometric numbers along the reaction routes are given. The reaction step 2 is the rate-determining catalytic step, since the reaction of the activated methanol with the diffused CO2 is postulated to be slow in comparison to the other reaction steps. Step 4 represents the non-catalytic liquid-phase reaction for the formation of methoxybutanol. The kinetic equation can be derived from coverage of the reacting species as follows: (3) K 1 = θ MeOH MeOH θ v ⇒ θ MeOH = K 1 MeOH θ v (4) K 3 = DMC BG θ v MB θ MC ⇒ θ MC = DMC BG θ v K 3 MB . The balance equation for the sites is (5) θ v + θ MeOH + θ MC = 1 . Combination of Eqs. (3–5) gives the coverage of the vacant adsorption sites (6) θ v = 1 1 + K 1 MeOH + DMC BG / K 3 MB . The reaction rate for step 2 can be written as follows: (7) r 2 = k 2 θ MeOH P CO 2 − k − 2 θ MC . Substituting the respective coverages into Eq. The value of K can be obtained from the experimental data. The rate for step 4 can be expressed as (9) r 4 = k 4 BO MeOH . The equilibrium constant for step 5 can be written as (10) K 5 = DMC H 2 O θ v 2 θ MeOH θ MC ⇒ θ MC = DMC H 2 O θ v 2 K 5 θ MeOH . Since the coverage of the intermediate adsorbed species θ MC is the same in Eqs. DMC is formed via two parallel routes, i.e. reactions (3) and (5), thus the following mass balance can be written as (13) H 2 O + BG = DMC . Substituting Eq. (12) into Eq. (13) enables the elimination of the concentration of water. The following relation is obtained: (14) BG 1 + K 1 K 5 K 3 MeOH MB = DMC , which can be rewritten as (15) DMC − BG MeOH / MB = K 1 K 5 K 3 BG = α BG . A test plot (Fig. 11 ) is linear, thus confirming that Eq. (15) is able to describe the experimental data. The water concentration can be obtained from Eq. (13). From the reaction rates and the stoichiometric scheme, the rate for the formation of DMC, methoxybutanol, butylene carbonate, and the rate of decomposition of butylene oxide and methanol in the batch reactor can be written as follows: (16) d DMC d t = r 2 ρ B (17) d MB d t = ( r 4 − γ r 2 ρ B ) ω (18) d BG d t = r 4 − ( r 4 − γ r 2 ρ B ) ω (19) d BO d t = − r 4 (20) d MeOH d t = − 2 r 2 ρ B − ( r 4 − γ r 2 ρ B ) ω , where ρ B is the bulk density of the catalyst, and γ and ω are merged quantities arising from a rigorous treatment of mass balances (available from authors, see notation). 5.2 Parameter estimation The numerical parameter estimation was based on the kinetic experiments in which the temperature and pressure were maintained constant, and the changes in the concentration of the species were recorded by gas chromatography. The model predictions of the kinetic parameters were obtained by solving the ordinary differential equations (ODEs; Eqs. (16–19)), which describe the mass balances. A rapid and stable prediction of the components was obtained by applying the backward differential method using the software ModEst [21], employing a stiff ODE solver [22] and the residual sum of squares (Q) was minimised by a combined simplex Levenberg–Marquardt algorithm according to Eq. (21): (21) Q = ∑ ( c i ( t ) − c ˆ i ( t ) ) 2 , where the estimated concentrations ( c ˆ i ) were obtained from the models, and the concentrations (c i ) were obtained from the laboratory experiments. Fig. 12 shows that the simulated curves obtained were in good agreement with the experimental points. The initial parameter estimation showed that the inclusion of the equilibrium constants, K 1 and K 3 in the parameter estimations, resulted in an over-parameterised system and did not improve the fit of the model to the experimental data. The constants K 1 and K 3 correlated with the rate constant k 2, therefore, solving for the parameters resulted in high relative errors (>1000%). As a result, α and β, a function of K 1 and K 3 respectively, were set to zero. The estimated values at 150°C for the kinetic parameters k 2 and k 4 and the errors are summarised in Table 1 . The residual sum of squares obtained was 0.046 and the degree of explanation was 99.98%. The activation energy was obtained by performing separate regression analysis at 120, 150 and 180°C. The results provided different values for the rate constant k 2, from which the slope (E a/R) was obtained from the plot of the natural logarithms versus the inverse of the respective temperatures. The activation energy estimated was 62±6.6kJ/mol. 6 Conclusions The kinetics of the synthesis of DMC from methanol and CO2 using butylene oxide as a chemical trap for water over ZrO2–MgO was studied with the temperature range 120–180°C. Mass transfer resistances were eluded by using catalysts with particle sizes <100μm and 700rpm of stirring speed. The methanol-to-butylene oxide ratio of 30 showed a reasonable conversion of methanol and DMC selectivity at 150°C. DMC and butylene glycol were formed via the reaction of adsorbed mono-methoxycarbonate intermediate and methoxybutanol. DMC was also formed via the mono-methoxycarbonate reaction with methanol, producing water as by-product in the absence of butylene oxide. Regression analysis performed for the advanced mechanism provided reasonable description of the concentration dependencies of the species over time for reactions performed at different temperatures. The apparent activation energy was determined as 62kJ/mol. coredata.dc:description: A kinetic investigation of dimethyl carbonate (DMC) synthesis from methanol and CO2 over ZrO2–MgO was performed by using butylene oxide as a chemical trap for the water formed during the reaction. The effect of the catalyst amount, the stirring speed, the temperature, as well as the amount of butylene oxide on the reaction rate and the selectivity to DMC was studied. The analysis of the reaction pathway suggests that DMC and butylene glycol are formed via the reaction of adsorbed mono-methoxycarbonate intermediate and methoxybutanol or methanol. A kinetic model was developed based on the reaction mechanism and it was in agreement with the experimental data. The apparent activation energy for the formation of DMC was 62kJ/mol.
coredata.dc:title: Kinetics of dimethyl carbonate synthesis from methanol and carbon dioxide over ZrO2–MgO catalyst in the presence of butylene oxide as additive
